content.question: Three identical but nonideal batteries are connected to resistors in three different circuits, as shown in the figure. The dashed-line box encloses the battery in each circuit. How do the potential differences <math alttext="delta V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="delta V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> across the terminals of the batteries in the three circuits compare?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta V sub 1 equals delta V sub 2, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 1 equals delta V sub 3, which is greater than delta V sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 2 is greater than delta V sub 1, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="delta V sub 3 is greater than delta V sub 2, which is greater than delta V sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="delta V sub 2 is greater than delta V sub 1, which equals delta V sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
